unnormalised: Hey everyone, welcome back to the blog! Today, I wanted to chat about something we all go through – exam results and grading systems. Specifically, I've been thinking a lot about how our academic system in India presents and interprets marks. It's quite a ride, isn't it?
normalised: Hey everyone, welcome back to the blog! Today, I wanted to chat about something we all go through – exam results and grading systems. Specifically, I've been thinking a lot about how our academic system in India presents and interprets marks. It's quite a ride, isn't it?

unnormalised: Remember that heart-stopping moment when the CBSE Class 10 results were announced? I recall logging in frantically, only to see a grand total of 85% flashing on the screen. Honestly, the percentage felt more like a judgment than a reflection of my actual knowledge. And the pressure! Aunties and uncles comparing notes on whose kid got 90% vs. 92%. Madness, I tell you.
normalised: Remember that heart-stopping moment when the C-B-S-E Class ten results were announced? I recall logging in frantically, only to see a grand total of eighty five percent flashing on the screen. Honestly, the percentage felt more like a judgment than a reflection of my actual knowledge. And the pressure! Aunties and uncles comparing notes on whose kid got ninety percent versus ninety two percent. Madness, I tell you.

unnormalised: Then comes Class 12. Talk about high stakes! Suddenly, you’re not just competing with your class; you’re vying for a spot in Delhi University, IIT, or some other prestigious institution. Your JEE score or NEET ranking becomes your identity. I remember a friend who scored 98.5% but didn't crack IIT. The disappointment was palpable. He felt like that .5% defined him.

Suddenly, you’re not just competing with your class; you’re vying for a spot in Delhi University, I-I-T, or some other prestigious institution. Your J-E-E score or N-E-E-T ranking becomes your identity. I remember a friend who scored ninety eight point five percent but didn't crack I-I-T. The disappointment was palpable. He felt like that point five percent defined him.

unnormalised: And let’s not forget the grading systems within universities. Some colleges follow the CGPA system (Cumulative Grade Point Average), where a 10-point scale determines your overall performance. Others stick to percentages. My cousin studying at Mumbai University often complains that getting a mere 70% in a subject feels like a failing grade compared to his friends in other colleges. He says, "It's like getting a C when everyone else is getting A's!"

unnormalised: Now, let’s talk about internal assessments vs. external exams. Some colleges give significant weightage to internal assessments (maybe 40%), which includes assignments, presentations, and attendance. Others rely almost entirely on the end-of-semester exams (worth 80% or even 90%). This disparity can be super stressful, especially if you’re someone who shines in project work but crumbles under exam pressure.

unnormalised: Then there are the professional courses. Getting a first-class degree (usually 60% and above) in engineering or medicine is often considered the bare minimum. To really stand out, you need to aim for a distinction (75% or higher). And if you’re dreaming of an MBA, your CAT score is king. People with a 99 percentile get interview calls from IIMs, while others with slightly lower scores have to settle for less. Talk about a cutthroat competition!

People with a ninety nine percentile get interview calls from I-I-M-s, while others with slightly lower scores have to settle for less. Talk about a cutthroat competition!

unnormalised: Ultimately, I think it’s important to remember that academic results are just one piece of the puzzle. Whether you score 60% or 95%, it doesn't define your worth or your potential. Skills, passion, and perseverance matter just as much, if not more. So, take a deep breath, celebrate your achievements, and don't let those numbers dictate your path. What do you think?
